captions.text:
This isn't looking good at all. What was supposed
to be an easy day hike, is quickly turning

into a life-threatening situation. One of
your top priorities is to get a fire going

before nightfall, but all you've got with
you is a bag lunch and an empty water bottle.

This is a challenge that's going to require
a little creativity. You're going to have
to light this fire, with your pee!

For this project you're gonna need some
of that special yellow liquid, and the timing

is great because with all that water you drank,
nature is calling. You can use a container

like your water bottle to collect as much
as possible. Now, that's really not a lot,

and it looks like you're still a little dehydrated,
but you're gonna have to make it work.

When you flip the bottle over and attempt
the water bottle trick from a previous video,

it doesn't seem to be working. And that's
because you don't have enough fluid in your

bottle. You try removing the label to see
if that helps, but it's not making much of

a difference. Ok, time to check your lunch
bag to see what other resources you have.

There's a bag of celery sticks that could
be useful. But here's something even better…

…you wrapped your apple with a plastic wrap.
Perfect! Carefully remove the wrapper, making

sure not to rip it, and now you're gonna
need some rocks. When you place these rocks

in a circle, they've formed a crude concave
mold. The rocks help form the wrapper into

a bowl shape, and now you can add the liquid.
When it's filled to the edges, grab all the

sides, and hold them together at the top,
making this into a little liquid pouch. Twisting

this pouch, while holding at the top, helps
remove any air and seals the liquid inside.

When you twist the excess plastic around your
middle finger like a ring, then wrap it around

the base to hold it in place, the pressure
can be adjusted, and you've got yourself a

great little liquid lens that's easy to use!
It's magnifying very well, so time to test

it out on some tinder. One of the unneeded
pages from your map should work perfectly,

so focus the sunlight on the darkest ink you
can find, because this will absorb the heat.

It's incredible how quickly this starts smoking,
and where there's smoke, there's a hope of

fire! A hole is burning in the paper now,
and when it's about the size of a quarter

it's pretty well self sustaining. Without
wasting any time, try adding layers of dry

grass, and blowing gently to add some air.
It's getting hot, and smoking quite a bit,

so just blow a little stronger, and success!
You've got a flame. Now get that to a place

you can build your fire up, and it's finished!
You just lit a fire with your pee. Well there's

a little trick most people will never have
to use, but might be good to know just in

case. If you liked this project, perhaps you'll
like some of my others. Check them out at
www.thekingofrandom.com

transparent enough. Besides lager or pee, you can start a fire with water, 
vodka, tequila, white rum, white wine, peppermint schnapps, gin, tonic 
water, 7-up, or Canada Dry.

comments.text:

comments.author: stevefm fm

comments.text:
+Walter Haynie Walter if you are 'stuck' in the wilderness then you have 
what broken legs? Well here's new for you, you won't be able to gather fuel 
with broken legs. If you are just lost then the best thing to do is walk 
out. Guess what, you can't carry a fire with you. Carrying embers, possible 
but an extremely skilled job needing hours of prep and the right materials. 
The point is Walter in 95% of the escape scenarios you should be building a 
fire each night where you stop and this method is USELESS for that. So you 
need to know OTHER methods. Also in many parts of the world the sun is an 
infrequent visitor. Infact, where you would most need a fire (cold climate) 
you might not see then sun for weeks on end. Enjoy being cold, wet and 
hungry.
comments.author: stevefm fm

comments.text:
+stevefm fm If I'm stuck in the wilderness, I'm keeping my fire going 24/7. 
If it rains, it becomes a lot harder to start a fire with wet fuel than 
dry. Pretty easy to keep a fire going with wet fuel though, as the fire 
dries it out before it starts burning. If I need to move, guess what? I'm 
bringing embers with me. Starting a fire without a lighter/match can be a 
real bitch, especially if your fuel is wet. Much easier to gather fuel to 
maintain fire than it is to start one.
comments.author: Walter Haynie

comments.text:
welcome to the toxic internet, where a certain person... cough cough,

comments.author: cookiedough1796

comments.text:
+crazyfvck It's a crazy idea but it might just work. Let me know how you 
get on.

You do realise as a strategy it also binds you to a single location and 
means you can't walk yourself out of trouble? Or at the very best you can 
walk from say 6am till midday. I don't think being unable to spend the many 
many hours of daylight exploring an escape route is a good idea ATALL. So 
I'll say again - this is good for a signal fire but NOTHING else. If you 
need warmth and cooking facilities at the end of a day of trying to walk 
towards civilisation you need to be able to light a fire at the END OF THE 
DAY. This technique will not work when you need it. 

Now THAT is SIMPLE.
comments.author: stevefm fm

comments.text:
+stevefm fm You are saying that someone needs to create a fire that starts 
at mid-day, and then keep it going 20 hours overnight. Then I said you 
don't need to make a roaring fire (or even a fire at that.) All you need is 
to use his technique to create a pile of smoldering embers. Then, when 
night comes and you actually need a fire, you can use the embers to light 
one. Simple.
comments.author: crazyfvck

hours in less than 2hrs let us all know how. Without an axe or saw mind.
